repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This Pull Request changes [Embedding Cython modules in C/C++ applications](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/embedding.html) , adds essential documentation for the new `--embed-modules` feature , which was implemented in #4978 (thanks to @matusvalo) .

**Key content improvements:**

1.  **New Section Added:** Added a new section, "Embedding multiple modules," which documents the usage of the `cython --embed --embed-modules` option and provides a full working example.
2.  **Updating Quick Links:** Updated the "Quick links" section to replace the outdated reference to the `cython_freeze` with the new option `cython --embed-modules` .
3.  **Subtitle Changing:** Renamed the section title from "Embedding example code" to "Embedding a single module" to clearly distinguish it from the new multi-module functionality.
4.  **Change Position of Warning:** Removed the mentions of the `cython_freeze` and consolidated the general warning regarding application portability (external dependencies) from the end of the "Embedding a single module" section into the new "Embedding multiple modules" section.


**Related to:** #4978

comment_data.body: This short example was a little confusing to me just because it seems like part of the `lcmath+combinatorics` example that follows. I think don't use `lcmath` on this line (just to make it clearer that it isn't part of that example)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -69,19 +68,61 @@ The C ``main()`` function of your program could look like this:
 <https://docs.python.org/3/extending/extending.html#the-module-s-method-table-and-initialization-function>`_.)
 
 Instead of writing such a ``main()`` function yourself, you can also let
-Cython generate one into your module's C file with the ``cython --embed``
-option.  Or use the
-`cython_freeze <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/bin/cython_freeze>`_
-script to embed multiple modules.  See the
-`embedding demo program <https://github.com/cython/cython/tree/master/Demos/embed>`_
-for a complete example setup.
-
-Be aware that your application will not contain any external dependencies that
-you use (including Python standard library modules) and so may not be truly portable.
-If you want to generate a portable application we recommend using a specialized
-tool (e.g. `PyInstaller <https://pyinstaller.org/en/stable/>`_
-or `cx_freeze <https://cx-freeze.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html>`_) to find and
-bundle these dependencies.
+Cython generate one into your module's C file with the :option:`cython --embed` option.
+
+
+Embedding multiple modules
+==========================
+
+To statically link multiple Cython modules into a single executable, you must use the
+:option:`cython --embed-modules` option alongside the :option:`cython --embed` option.
+This option enables the necessary C-level initialisation calls (via :c:func:`PyImport_AppendInittab`)
+for all listed modules within the main program's C code.
+
+The argument is a comma-separated list of the module names you wish to embed:
+
+.. code-block:: bash
+
+    cython --embed --embed-modules=lcmath,another_module main_script.pyx

comment_data.body: Thanks for the suggestion, I agree that was confusing. I've updated the line 86 to use generic names (mod1, mod2) and pushed the fix. Please take another look!

Sorry,I have removed the space between mod1 and mod2 and push again.

commit.message: Adds the new 'Embedding multiple modules' section to tutorial/embedding.rst
replace lcmath with mod1 in line 86

title: Doc: Document the new --embed-modules option in tutorials(embedding.rst)
